items.title: 'Evidence spoke louder' than abusive ex's lies in years-long court battle
items.description: Former Darwin councillor Paul Arnold was found guilty of domestic violence after a years-long court battle, with his ex-partner refusing to be scared into silence. She said the case was "stressful and deeply humiliating", but facing her abuser had been empowering.

items.title: Race to rescue missing worker after Queensland mine collapse
items.description: A man remains unaccounted-for after a roof collapse at the Curragh mining complex in Central Queensland.

items.title: Mum's urgent BBQ warning after suffering face, body burns
items.description: Rachel Dear has a serious warning for anyone using a gas barbecue after she suffered significant face and body burns while cooking on Christmas Eve.

items.title: World-first organ donation after mum self-administers VAD medication
items.description: An Australian woman is believed to have become the first person in the world to donate organs after self-administering oral voluntary assisted dying medication.

items.title: Political outlook 'dramatically shifted' after Bondi
items.description: What are you watching in Australian politics in 2026? That's the question we put to the ABC's political journalists and columnists.

items.title: Two truths and a lie: Inside the China-Taiwan-US triangle
items.description: The US has no intention of abandoning Taiwan. But it also has no intention of binding itself to an automatic war commitment on a timeline it does not control.

items.title: 'Irresponsible': Sparklers and venue become focus of Swiss bar blaze probe
items.description: The prevalence of sparklers at a Swiss ski resort bar where dozens of people died in a fire this week has been branded "irresponsible", as authorities probe potential compliance issues there.

items.title: Millions of coffee pods go to landfill. Here's what is being done about it
items.description: Between 10 and 20 per cent of the 3 million coffee pods Australians consume daily are actually recycled. Here's what's being done to change that.

items.title: 'I just screamed': Storm chaser captures rare red sprites in WA sky
items.description: A storm chaser captures a rare, split-second phenomenon above a thunderstorm.

items.title: Grok under fire over complaints it let users undress minors in photos
items.description: The generative AI chatbot integrated with X is under international scrutiny after reports it was filling the social media platform with sexually explicit images of children and women.

items.title: Flooded Qld graziers to get $2m support as pilots muster stranded livestock
items.description: Floodwaters remain in outback Queensland as graziers start to tally up livestock losses. Major flooding is possible in the north-west, with king tides forecast on the east coast.

items.title: Police riot squad to carry long-arm firearms at Sydney Ashes series
items.description: Officers will carry long-arm firearms as part of a bolstered police presence at the Ashes series in Sydney in the wake of the Bondi terror attack.

items.title: Man dies after shooting near police station in Melbourne's inner north
items.description: Police are searching for offenders, who are believed to have driven past in a silver SUV and fired shots at a young man, before fleeing the scene.

items.title: A 'haven' for sailors on Queensland's coast, with tales of hidden treasure
items.description: Middle Percy Island is a rare gem where boaties can come ashore and wander through thousands of mementos left by travellers from across the globe.

items.title: Red and yellow flags can be confusing. Is it time to change them?
items.description: Every summer, millions of Australians head to the beach and every year thousands are rescued by lifeguards or surf life savers, and even surfers or other bystanders.

items.title: NSW drownings toll rises after desperate attempts to save spearfisher
items.description: The man was pulled unresponsive from the water at a remote beach south of Wollongong after he was tangled in a float line.

items.title: It was a photo that, if leaked, was illegal. Now it's on public display
items.description: What started as a chance discovery of an old photo at a Dallas antique store has spawned a collection of more than 4,000 images of male couples, more than 100 of which are now on display in Canberra.

items.title: The parts of Myanmar the military junta don't want you to see
items.description: Myanmar's military is holding its first elections since overthrowing a democratically elected government in 2021. But as it aims to portray a sense of normality, signs of the junta's menacing presence are everywhere.

items.title: Pakistan sentences journalists to life in prison over pro-Khan protests
items.description: Eight journalists and social media commentators are sentenced to life imprisonment in Pakistan after being convicted of terrorism-related offences linked to online activity in support of jailed former prime minister Imran Khan.

items.title: Yemen separatists announce plans to split nation after 20 killed in Saudi-led strikes
items.description: A military official from the separatist group, which is backed by the United Arab Emirates, said that 20 fighters had been killed in air raids by the Saudi-backed coalition in the south of the country.

items.title: Tesla loses title of world's bestselling EV company as sales drop
items.description: Tesla sales have declined for the second consecutive year, with Chinese rival BYD surpassing it as the world's largest electric vehicle maker.

items.title: Aussies coy about Green's role in final Ashes Test
items.description: Steve Smith launches an impassioned defence of the out-of-form Cameron Green, but cannot guarantee the all-rounder's place in Australia's XI for the final Ashes Test.

items.title: Australian prime beef producers brace for fresh China tariff pain
items.description: Australian cattle farmers producing wagyu and Angus beef are likely to be among the hardest hit by China's 55 per cent tariff on exports exceeding a 205,000-tonne quota.

items.title: How this little bird ended up on South Australia's most wanted list
items.description: The sighting of a single red-whiskered bulbul in the wild might not seem like a big deal, but this invasive pest could put crops and the environment at risk.

items.title: P-plater arrested for alleged street racing at 209km/h on SA expressway
items.description: Police say two 19-year-old drivers will face court for street racing along Adelaide's Southern Expressway, with one of the P-platers allegedly detected speeding at 209km/h.
